instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_LEFT: What is HALL_SENSOR_LEFT? HALL_SENSOR_LEFT is a signal from the hall sensor on the left side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> requires SMC reset to turn on
threads.message:
After shutting down and closing lid, A1408 won't turn back on without first doing an SMC reset.
Shutting down without closing lid, machine turns back on without SMC reset.
No damage or liquid traces around hall sensor or SMC. 
When testing with trackpad cable unplugged (<SIGNAL>LID_OPEN</SIGNAL> disconnected), unit turns on fine and issue does not occur.

I have not diagnosed a hall sensor issue before and am not sure how to proceed with testing whilst being able to test with lid open/closed.
Can a magnet be used to test values out of chassis? I am not sure how to proceed.

NOTE: Liquid damage around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> resistors was repaired but issue pre-dated this charging fault. 

Thank you in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> requires SMC reset to turn on
threads.message:
Hall sensors may work if no problem disconnecting trackpad.
Something bad with trackpad, which affects <SIGNAL>LID_OPEN</SIGNAL> signal probably.
Check <SIGNAL>LID_OPEN</SIGNAL> level with lid open/close.

Just in case, check <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT signals too.
You can use magnets approached to the sensors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> requires SMC reset to turn on
threads.message:
Very strange. The issue is no longer present.
Even after an upgrade from High Sierra to Monteray, the issue had persisted.
Once booted without trackpad and 3.5mm board connected (which I believe houses the other sensor), SMC reset was performed, connectors brushed off and reconnected and it now works. I should mention that I had previously disconnected and inspected the connectors but did not brush them off (they looked great and were clean) nor perform an SMC reset in between reconnecting them.
I am not complaining, I just wish I knew what did it...

Thank you very much for getting back to me with help.
Should I delete the thread or leave it as strange as the "solution" may be?
